title: Amaranth (color)
text:
Amaranth is a <a href="red">red</a>dish-<a href="Rose%20%28color%29">rose</a> <a href="color">color</a> that is a representation of the color of the <a href="flower">flower</a> of the <a href="amaranth">amaranth</a> plant. The color shown is the color of the red amaranth flower (the color normally considered amaranth), but there are other varieties of amaranth that have other colors of amaranth flowers; these colors are also shown below.
Amaranth.
The color amaranth is displayed at right. This color is also called "amaranth red" to distinguish it from the varying colors of other varieties of the amaranth flower.
The color "amaranth" is similar to printer's <a href="magenta">magenta</a> (pigment magenta), but redder. It is the color of the flower of those <a href="amaranth">amaranth</a> plants that have "amaranth red" colored flowers.
The first recorded use of "amaranth" as a color name in <a href="English%20language">English</a> was in 1690.
Etymology.
The name "amaranth" comes from the <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> "a" (not) + "marainean" (to waste away), i.e., a flower believed to grow on <a href="Mount%20Olympus">Mount Olympus</a> which never died.
Variations of amaranth.
Amaranth pink.
The color amaranth pink is displayed at right. This color is a representation of the color of pink <a href="amaranth">amaranth</a> flowers.
The first recorded use of "amaranth pink" as a color name in English was in 1905. 
Radical red (bright amaranth pink).
The <a href="Crayola">Crayola</a> <a href="crayon">crayon</a> color radical red is displayed at right.
The color "radical red", which may also be called bright amaranth pink, was formulated by Crayola in 1990.
This color is supposed to be <a href="fluorescent">fluorescent</a>, but there is no mechanism for displaying fluorescence on a computer screen. 
Amaranth purple.
The color amaranth purple is displayed at right. This color is a representation of the color of purple amaranth flowers.
The first recorded use of "amaranth purple" as a color name in <a href="English%20language">English</a> was in 1912.
Amaranth deep purple.
Amaranth deep purple is the tone of amaranth that is called "amaranth" in the 1930 book by Maerz and Paul "A Dictionary of Color". 
Alizarin.
Alizarin is the tone of amaranth that is called "alizarin" in the 1930 book by Maerz and Paul "A Dictionary of Color".
